comments.text:
http://zidbits.com/2011/04/why-cant-anything-go-faster-than-the-speed-of-light/

"Einstein once called the speed of light “The Universe’s speed limit”. He 
claimed that traveling faster than the speed of light would violate the 
causality principle. For the layman, that means cause and effect. An 
example of this would be a bullet hitting a target before the trigger was 
even pulled.

Accelerating to light speed or exceeding it would also violate certain 
fundamental energy conditions. It could even allow for time travel."

Did I look that up enough for you? The only circumstance where a particle 
or object with mass can travel faster than the speed of light is when the 
universe around it is distorted and though it actually isn't faster than 
light it seems that way to an observer.

I see a lot of posts regarding about the possibility of traveling faster 
than speed of light. However, what you don't understand is that the burden 
of proof is on you. Einstein had proven his theory, and nothing 
scientifically says that you can travel faster than light itself. If you 
believe so much in such notion and are convinced that it's the right thing, 
then you should prove it before saying that c is not the speed limit of our 
universe. Apparently, ranging from electrodynamics, quantum mechanics, to 
relativity, it was proven by theory and experiment that c = constraint of 
our universe. Although you can say that it's just a limited version of the 
complete theory of our universe, you have to prove that your facts are 
right before saying otherwise....

comments.text:
The brain has a special thing where if part of it is damaged, the function 
of that part of the brain can be put into a separate part of the brain, 
like bypassing the damaged part, its not always the case but popular enough 
that its become quite well known. Its basically the brain reprogramming 
itself and even when you may be left with issues like seizures, you can 
still function almost the same, other people do incur worse problems 
though, like memory or speech issues. The mind technically does not exist 
inside the brain, it uses the brain as a vessel for programming power, like 
the brain is the hardware and the mind is the software, so essentially the 
mind can just use different wires in the brain to pass the same bit of 
information along, im trying to keep this simple for you but unsure if its 
simple enough.

speed of light. Here is the wiki article containing the equation.

top_comment.text:
My mother survived a rebar pole thru her face. A truck ran the pole over on 
the freeway and flipped it up. Another driver saw the scene unfold. The guy 
said she had pulled over and once he got over to her car she had already 
pulled the pole out of her head. She doesn't remember any of that. The 
doctors only let us see her in the hospital because they thought she was 
going to die. 8 years later she is still driving past the scene of the 
accident. 45 minute drive to work, working 4-5 days a week, ranging 
anywhere from 40- 60 hour work weeks. She hardly ever gets to take a break 
or lunch at work; thats what happens when you are an assistant manager at 
walmart, and your boss is doing anything he can to fire you. This woman 
runs on 4 hours of sleep. If that doesn't motivate yuh than you don't 
believe it. I don't blame you, I have a hard time wrapping my mind around 
it.﻿

My dad had a terrible upbringing and was abused by his stepdad, he survived 
almost being hit by a truck at age 4 (if it werent for my gran yelling his 
name he would have been killed), getting smacked over the head with a 
baseball bat by a douchebag at age 12, getting stabbed through the wrist 
with a knife at age 16 (that was his fault because he was stupid), getting 
his face slashed by a glass bottle at age 19 (for which he now has a scar 
across his left cheek), getting beat up by 4 drunken guys at age 20, being

You are either young or uneducated and not knowledgeable about what you 
speak of. There are theories that there are multiple universes and it is 
thought the universe is infinite. Both of these are unknowns because there 
is currently no way to test for these other than with arithmetic. Also we 
believe that the occupied space in our universe is limited, since there was 
a big bang and all matter had a starting point, then everything in the 
universe must be centered around that point. Knowing this the universe 
cannot be filled if it is infinite and there is a "boundary". Also since 
vision is limited by the speed of light, only certain areas of the universe 
can be observed so we would not be able to see a boundary whether there was 
one or not. Anyways, I do not know a lot on astrophysics and astronomy and 
space, but if you are going to go on some rant and then support it (with

looking at for things that are theoretical. Think about gravity for 
instance. We believed Newton's definition for gravity for ~300 years, then 
Einstein comes along and disproves it with the theory of relativity, making 
the scientific community speechless by disproving what was thought to be 
scientific law.

“The only true wisdom is in knowing you know nothing.”

comments.text:
While the lighter isotopes 12C and 13C are stable, the heaviest isotope 14C 
(radiocarbon) is radioactive. This means its nucleus is so large that it is 
unstable. Over time 14C decays to nitrogen (14N). Most 14C is produced in 
the upper atmosphere where neutrons, which are produced by cosmic rays, 
react with 14N atoms. That is how Carbon dating, you're making no sense. If 
you went to school they taught you how many dating systems work. You didn't 
need to be alive 500-1000 years ago, with modern day science they see how 
much the carbon 14 has decayed over the years and trace it. That's the 
simplest way of explaining it. If you think the earth is thousands of years 
old, you are too dumb.

comments.text:
+TheMajorpickle01 Dude thank you for being one of two or three logical 
people here.
    The speed of light can't really be broken, that's because photons have 
no mass, therefore, anything with mass cannot reach c (the speed of light), 
because you would keep inputting more and more energy asymptotically 
 without ever hitting c. Even saying that you can accelerate something 
faster than light, is saying that Einstein's greatest accomplishment of the 
equation E=Mc^2 is wrong, algebraically, if you're saying a particle can go 
faster than light is saying that E<Mc^2, which is like saying if you buy a 
pint of ice cream, you get two, the second appearing out of nowhere.
    Secondly, particle accelerators exist not to go faster than the speed 
of light, but to input massive amounts of energy into a few hundred protons 
to collide with a piece of a heavy element to reproduce the effects of the 
initial state of the big bang with the intent to discover novel particles.
    Thirdly, someone said that the god particle, aka the Higgs' boson, can 
travel faster than light? We have only discovered this particle in the past 
few years, it only exists for a brief moment only to evaporate into the 
universe's Higgs field. We've never measured its speed, but I can assure 
you that because it has mass, it will never travel at, or faster, than the 
speed of light.

All these things are taught to you in high school; I'm ashamed.

+Austin A That project was abandoned as the Soviet Union collapsed. It

comments.author: Andy Lee

comments.text:
+TheGamerCyclops Now, first i want to dictate that make sure you take note 
of what your research is pinpointing. The article you labeled and 
emphasized so greatly in itself contradicts your own proposal. 

The speed of light is constant and will remain as our universal constant; 
meaning nothing can break this limit of velocity. The article indicates 
that the universe is *expanding* to the point where it reaches the speed of 
light. Actually its expanding faster than the speed of light, right now. 
However, this does not imply that it breaks the theory of special 
relativity. If it did, there would be a paradigm shift in physics. That 
hasn't happened. 

Special relativity states that nothing can move faster than the speed of 
light *within* the universe. It doesn't stipulate that the universe cant. 
The article sort of creates a misconception when it states galaxies 
immensely far away from the Earth are traveling faster and faster; a red 
shift, close to the speed of light. Right, but the space between the earth 
and the galaxy is expanding at that rate, not the galaxy itself.
comments.author: Andy Lee

comments.text:
+Boom, logic. not for nothing, but matter is not just fermions.  The only 
fundamental boson that has no mass is the photon.  Gluons, the W and Z 
bozons and the Higgs all have a large amount of mass.

Also, photons can't be crammed into a bose-einstein condensate.  What *can* 
be crammed into a condensate are composite bosons (i.e. particles with a 
net integer spin) like rubidium atoms.  Further, even non-composite-bosons 
can be coaxed into a condensate by pairing with each other, though this is 
usually at much lower temperatures than composite bosons.  Probably the 
most well-known instance of this is the Cooper-pair, a composite boson 
formed from the pairing of two electrons.  This circumventing of the Pauli 
exclusion principle is responsible for superconduction.
comments.author: htomerif

comments.author: kailey fladung

comments.text:
Okay, I read the one about someone pointing a laser at the moon and 
flicking your wrist, and I wanted to correct it. Nothing there's moves 
faster than the speed of light. Think of the laser as a water hose; if 
you'd point the hose at something, and then flicked your wrist, the water 
shooting out would become an arc. It's the same with a laser; the beam 
would become an arc, but because light's so fast, it seems like it stayed 
straight the whole time
comments.author: Erick Hernandez

been known to happen and is imaginable is at the point of the big bang were 
the laws of physics did not apply. Massless particles can go the speed of

light, even 99% of it but never faster. Yes I've heard of neutrinos and 
other particles that people say can go faster than light, but there is no 
evidence except for flawed clunky experiments that can't be trusted to 
support this. So, so far non of the main stream physicists believe anything

comments.text:
I certainly wouldn't presume to explain the many catastrophes that are 
permitted in a realm that we think is overseen by our supreme being, whom 
we call God.  I can share one story that happened to me in 1991.  My 
daughter asked that we go to a movie that had recently been released, 
"Ghost", in which a young couple, Patrick Swayze and Demi Moore, recently 
married, were stalked by one of her office mates who was desirous of a 
relationship with the Demi character.  Thwarted by her recent marriage, her 
office mate contracted with several villainous acquaintances to murder the 
young husband to clear the way for his advances.  The husband, now 
dispatched and on the other side of death, pursued a more talented denizen 
of purgatory (if you will), who had learned how to move small objects still 
in the world of the living.  He amused himself by snapping bottle caps on 
subway cars to scare riders who could see no means by which they were 
animated.  The young husband now sets out to warn his young widow to avoid 
the associate who had arranged for his demise.  He engages Whoopi Goldberg, 
a "charlatan" seer/fortune teller to help convince his widow of the danger. 
 That convincing occurred using the vehicle of running a penny up the 
inside of a closed door, defying gravity in the process.  On our way home 
from the feature film, my daughter suggested that since I was 30 some years 
older than she was, that I would probably die before she would.  She asked 
that if that eventuality occurred, that I find some way to use pennies to 
let her know that I'd arrived in Heaven.  I promised that if the talent 
displayed by the young husband could be duplicated on the Heaven side of 
the veil, that I would certainly do it.  My daughter had been stalked by an 
acquaintance who wanted to date her.  She was in the preliminary stages of 
being engaged and wanted nothing to do with the young man.  He lured her 
away from my home on the pretext that because she wouldn't date him, he was 
going to commit suicide.  Instead of killing himself, he killed her that 
night.  I was desolated.  Several weeks later I returned to work.  When I 
was retiring one night, I remembered my promise to use pennies to let her 
know I was in Heaven.  In my prayers that evening, I asked her to find a 
way to use pennies to let me know that she'd made it all the way to Heaven. 
 The very next day I headed off to work at the bank where I was an officer 
with a designated parking place in their lot.  I went to exit my car, 
extended my leg to put my foot on the ground.  It hit something slippery. 
 I looked down to see 13 bright, shiny, brand new pennies laying there.  Of 
course, I picked them up.  From that day to today, I've been blessed with 
welters of pennies.  Before I moved across the country in 2003, I'd 
collected two, five gallon Hinckley & Schmidt water bottles full of 
pennies.  I had not told anyone of the conversation Rachel and I had that 
night.  I can't imagine that a 17 year old would would tell her friends of 
such a conversation she had with her father, and yet the pennies have 
continued to pursue me.  I have no choice but to believe that Rachel made 
it.  I have no choice but to believe that God and Heaven exist.  You will 
have to construct your own belief system based on your own experiences.  I 
have my proof almost every day.  Good Luck!  RobtheElder

comments.text:
About 2 years ago while in Afghanistan, I was patrolling and a damn rocket 
launcher hit our baby tanker. A piece of the seat lodged into the drivers 
skull and we had to get out in the heat of fire. We got out and I fell the 
the ground on the passenger side and once I did, another rocket hit the 
same side again and I swear the damn baby tank was almost rocked to its 
side, but I pushed it with my legs and it went back on all fours. In 
another stroke of luck a grenade landed to my left and a rocket blew out 
the passenger side rear door and looking at the door I picked it up and 
used it as a shield. The force was so strong it made throw up. Then I 
remembered I had about 6 Semtex grenades (C4 grenades) and 6 regular 
grenades I swear I threw those shits as far as I could and aimed it to 
where I heard the gun shots coming from.... Then I saw a baby tank coming 
back for us, one dude in my baby tank was hit by a damn RPG right his legs 
and he flew maybe 10 feet away from impact. His rib age was ripped open, 
his guts where half burned , blood oozing out, his top skull crushed in and 
his legs and one arm ripped off .... I thee 3 flash bangs at enemy 
direction and got machine gun covering fire from the baby tank that came 
back for us....we must have hit at least 100mph getting the fuck out of 
there.... As soon as we were at a safe distance I exploded the c4 that was 
left In the truck ... All in all there was 4 survivors in my truck... That 
was something I will never forget... 

We went back the next day with at least 100 troops and there was at least 
40 killed by my grenades and the covering fire... 

After those types of firefights, you know you have to die in the field to 
have a complete life. 

I deploy again in 3 months. Destination is classified.
comments.author: J Med

top_comment.text:
My step-sister has brain cancer, And it is very severe too, The doctors had 
to give her chemo therapy. And I guess it was really bad, because she had 
to take a shower every thirty minutes so the chemo doesn't leak on to her 
skin and burn her. Anyways, She had no White blood cells, the doctors told 
my mom-- and her mom as well, that there is no way that she will survive.

So on Christmas eve, My mom was buying things for her funeral, when she got 
a call from the hospital, They told her that she has about... A hundred 
blood cells..? Can't really remember the number. The doctors were 
astonished by this.
 Everyone, Even the doctors called it a Christmas miracle. It *still* kind 
of shocks us to this day how quickly she got her blood cells.

It may be nothing like these stories, but it still is really amazing in my 
opinion. :)﻿

Anyway, I have six brothers all older than me, they dared me to climb the 
tree and jump on to the trampoline. 
Of course, being the yougest, you want to be cool around your brothers and 
show them that you're awesome! i did it.
Only, I jumped and hit the metal part- my arm did, anyway. All my brothers

saying : 'Am I cool yet?' XD Ahh.. childhood memories..

There was this other time, that our trampoline was really close to the

it around) I got on the roof, got one of those bins, and got a rake.
I got in the bin, and used the rake to push myself off of the roof to land 
on the trampoline. I... missed the trampoline... I somehow broke my leg. xD 
The stupid things you do as a child. :D

captions.text:
• From people getting lost in the desert
to the sole survivor of a terrifying plane

crash, we count 15 times people evaded deaths
in the harshest circumstances known to man

15 - Chris Stewart
• This is a story from Fareham, Hants with

a 12-year-old who was racing around in his
1,000CC Mini when it hit a barrier at 40mph

• In what is referred to as an internal
decapitation, Chris's skull was severed from

his spine and he was given a measly 10% chance
of survival, with doctors claiming he should've

died instantly
• Amazingly in 2006, they reattached his

skull using metal plates and bone grafts - and
within a few years he was off racing again

14 - Steven Callahan
• It was in January 1982 that Steven set

sail on his small sailboat from the Canary
Islands bound for the Carribean, but not even

one week later his ship sank in a storm, and
he was left adrift on an inflatable rubber

raft
• For 76 entire days he drifted with nothing

but a shirt, three pounds of food, some gear
and water - eventually he washed up on the

Bahamas
• He then wrote an autobiography of the

whole ordeal, so impressive that Ang Lee the
director of Life of Pi asked Steven to become

a film consultant on living aboard a life
raft

13 - Bethany Hamilton
• An early morning in November 2003 when

Bethany went surfing in Hawaii
• She was out with her best friend Alana

and their family when a tiger shark around
4 meters in length, rose out of the water

and tore Bethany's left arm clean off the
shoulder

• Instead of panicking or crying, this 13-year-old
girl swam back to shore with her one good

arm, even warning other swimmers nearby to
get out of the water

• Pretty much the toughest girl of all time
12 - Joe Simpson

• If you've ever seen the documentary, Touching
the Void, then you'll already know this guy's

story, but for those that don't:
• Joe was being lowered down a crevasse

because of a broken leg when he disappeared
from view, so his friend Simon Yates was forced

to cut the rope, sending Joe to what seemed
like certain death

• Instead, it turned into a 3 day fight
for survival in a frozen tundra, slowly moving

through the snow on a broken leg, half-frozen
until his return

• If you haven't seen the documentary, highly
recommend it, very powerful stuff

11 - Mark and Phil
• Another ice story, this one set in 1982

on the high slopes of New Zealand's tallest
mountain, Aoraki Mt. Cook

• The two men Mark Inglis and Phil Doole
built an ice cave to escape the blizzard,

waiting for it to pass, but unluckily it kept
up for 13 entire days - and all they had were

meagre rations with no prospect of warmth
• Unfortunately the circulation was cut

off in their legs and they had to be amputated,
which is something you should never have to

go through at 23 years of age
• Crazily enough, they still climb to this

day with Inglis becoming the first double
amputee to conquer Everest, losing fingers

and flesh in the process
10 - Juliane Koepcke

• 1971, 93 passengers aboard LANSA flight
508 when lightning struck the plane over the

Peruvian rain forests and it came crashing
down

• Juliane was blown out of the plane early
and landed two miles down the wreckage in

a dense thicket, where she only came out with
blindness in one eye, a broken collarbone

along with cuts and bruises
• She walked down the jungle following the

water running downstream until she found a
cabin where she waited for the owner to come

back
• She then got back to civilisation and

continued her studies to become a zoologist
9 - Anatoli Bugorski

• A formerly Soviet researcher at the Institute
for High Energy Physics working on the largest

particle accelerator at the time, the Synchrotron
U-70

• It was in 1978 that a malfunction forced
Bugorski to lean over a piece of equipment

and look inside the proton beam chamber - but
failed safety mechanisms did not turn off

the beam, and it went straight through his
skull at a speed faster than light

• He claims he saw a flash brighter than
a thousand suns, with no pain - but his face

swelled up and skin began to peel off
• Thankfully he survived without losing

any intelligence, but he gets fatigued easily,
he can't hear out his left ear and occasional

seizures
8 - Alcides Moreno

• A window cleaner who, in 2007, fell 47
storeys when their cable snapped alongside

his brother Edgar, who tragically fell to
his death

• Alcides on the other hand was left in
a coma with considerable damage to his body,

but soon afterwards he awoke and made a full
recovery, even walking despite damage to his

spinal cord
• One of the doctors quote: “If you’re

a believer in miracles, this would be one.
I’ve seen it all – or at least I think

I have – until something like this happens.”
7 - Ricky Megee

• April 2006, a man who showed up as a skeletal
figure near a cattle station in a remote area

of Australia
• He claims the last thing he remembered

was getting his car stolen and that he was
drugged by a hitchhiker, then he awoke to

find dingoes scratching at him
• He then lived 71 days off a diet of leeches,

frogs, snakes and insects with water from
a nearby dam and a makeshift shelter

• By the time he showed up again, he'd lost
over half his body weight coming in at 48

kilos
6 - Aron Ralston

• May 2003, an 800-pound boulder falls on
Aron's arm and traps it inside a canyon wall

• If this story sounds familiar, it's because
we saw it in the film 127 hours, in which

he spends 5 days trapped in a Utah canyon
with little food or water

• He went on to write a book about how he
used the boulder to snap his own arm, then

cut off the flesh with a pocket knife until
he could wander off and get rescued by some

hikers passing by
5 - Wenseslao Moguel

• A man in 1915 captured during the Mexican
Revolution, sentenced to death via firing

squad
• They filled him with eight bullets, and

then one more straight through his head - but
he survived, feigning death until the shooters

left
• He's gone on to be interviewed by Ripley

from Ripley's Believe It or Not, the story
of the man who survived a barrage of bullets

which, sadly, left him a little disfigured
4 - Truman Duncan

• A railroad switchman who endured a horrifying
ordeal - to have his body sliced clean in

half by a train
• It was 2006 when Truman fell off a moving

train in Cleburne and it sliced him in two,
but he managed to stay conscious - calling

both 911 and his family to inform them what
had happened

• After a three-week coma and 23 surgeries,
he came out confined to a wheelchair but very

much alive, surgeons claiming it was an absolute
miracle and he should not have survived

3 - Tami Oldham Ashcraft
• 1983, Tami and her boyfriend Richard Sharp

were sailing the South Pacific when a category
four hurricane blew up 19 days into a 30 day

crossing
• Their ship capsized and Tami, still in

the lower decks, was knocked unconscious - 27
hours later she awoke to find Richard gone,

no safety line or mainmast
• Fighting down the desire to give up, she

sailed for forty days on route to what she
thought was Hawaii, ending up in Hilo Harbor,

in shock but thankful to be alive
2 - Paul Templer

• 1990s, Paul was working as a river guide
with a tribe of native Zimbabwe when he received

a surprise attack from one of Africa's most
dangerous animals - the bull hippo

• While trying to save a colleague, the
hippo swallowed Paul's head, then got mauled

with rips in his foot, a severed arm, broken
ribs and holes in his chest cavity

• He then endured a seven hour operation
for his recovery, and went on leading safari

trips and public speaking for charities
1 - Mauro Prosperi

• The 1994 Marathon of the Sands in Morocco,
Mauro was performing the 6 day run when a

sandstorm caused him to lose his way
• He ended up forgetting which way he was

running, and instead ended up far, far away
from the track - within 36 hours he'd run

out of food and water, so he resorted to drinking
urine and eating bats and snakes

• He tried to commit suicide by slitting
his wrists, but dehydration caused his blood

to thicken, clotting each wound
• 9 days later he was found by some nomads
and taken to an Algerian hospital
